DataElement.preferredDefinition: the structural pattern of cancer cells used to define a diagnosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to histologic classification of a bladder tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A distensible musculomembranous organ serving as a receptacle for fluid, as the gallbladder.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the histologic type of a bladder tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 01/29/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: of or relating to or resembling papilla.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to or resembling papilla.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: PAPILLARY AND CIS

A neuroendocrine carcinoma composed of small malignant cells which are often said to resemble "oat cells" under the microscope.  Small cell carcinoma most often affects the lungs.  Clinically, this is often a rapidly growing cancer that spreads to distant sites early.

Concepts.definition: An aggressive, high-grade, and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. It is composed of malignant small cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from squamous epithelial cells.  Morphologically, it is characterized by the proliferation of atypical, often pleomorphic squamous cells.  Squamous cell carcinomas are graded by the degree of cellular differentiation as well, moderately, or poorly differentiated.  Well differentiated carcinomas are usually associated with keratin production and the presence of intercellular bridges between adjacent cells.  Representative examples are lung squamous cell carcinoma, skin squamous cell carcinoma, and cervical squamous cell carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from squamous epithelial cells.  Morphologically, it is characterized by the proliferation of atypical, often pleomorphic squamous cells.  Squamous cell carcinomas are graded by the degree of cellular differentiation as well, moderately, or poorly differentiated.  Well differentiated carcinomas are usually associated with keratin production and the presence of intercellular bridges between adjacent cells.  Representative examples are lung squamous cell carcinoma, skin squamous cell carcinoma, and cervical squamous cell carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm arising from the transitional epithelium, usually affecting the urinary bladder, ureter, or renal pelvis. It may or may not have a papillary configuration. It is graded 1 to 3 or 4 according to the degree of cellular differentiation and architectural patterns. Grade 1 transitional cell carcinoma is histologically benign but it may recur. Transitional cell carcinomas may also affect the upper respiratory tract and the ovaries.

Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm arising from the transitional epithelium, usually affecting the urinary bladder, ureter, or renal pelvis. It may or may not have a papillary configuration. It is graded 1 to 3 or 4 according to the degree of cellular differentiation and architectural patterns. Grade 1 transitional cell carcinoma is histologically benign but it may recur. Transitional cell carcinomas may also affect the upper respiratory tract and the ovaries.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A common cancer characterized by the presence of malignant glandular cells. Morphologically, adenocarcinomas are classified according to the growth pattern (e.g., papillary, alveolar) or according to the secreting product (e.g., mucinous, serous). Representative examples of adenocarcinoma are ductal and lobular breast carcinoma, lung adenocarcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma (hepatoma), colon adenocarcinoma, and prostate adenocarcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A common cancer characterized by the presence of malignant glandular cells.  Morphologically, adenocarcinomas are classified according to the growth pattern (e.g., papillary, alveolar) or according to the secreting product (e.g., mucinous, serous).  Representative examples of adenocarcinoma are ductal and lobular breast carcinoma, lung adenocarcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma (hepatoma), colon adenocarcinoma, and prostate adenocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A transitional cell carcinoma characterized by a micropapillary growth pattern. Typical example is the micropapillary variant of infiltrating bladder urothelial carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A transitional cell carcinoma characterized by a micropapillary growth pattern. Typical example is the micropapillary variant of infiltrating bladder urothelial carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm derived from the transitional epithelium of the urinary tract (urinary bladder, ureter, urethra, or renal pelvis).  It is frequently papillary. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the urothelial lining of the urinary tract (bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A usually aggressive malignant epithelial neoplasm composed of atypical cells which do not display evidence of glandular, squamous, or transitional cell differentiation.

Concepts.definition: A usually aggressive malignant epithelial neoplasm composed of atypical cells which do not display evidence of glandular, squamous, or transitional cell differentiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.

Concepts.definition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that arises in cells that appear spindle-shaped when viewed under a microscope. These cancers can occur in various places in the body, including the skin, lungs, kidney, breast, gastrointestinal tract, bone, and muscle.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of spindle cells and anaplastic morphologic features.  Giant cells and a sarcomatous component may also be present.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplastic cell containing cytoplasmic mucin. The presence of mucin pushes the nucleus of the cell to the periphery, assuming a configuration resembling a signet ring.

Concepts.definition: A neoplastic cell containing cytoplasmic mucin. The presence of mucin pushes the nucleus of the cell to the periphery, assuming a configuration resembling a signet ring.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasmacytoid
A clinical and/or pathologic primary tumor TNM finding indicating that the cancer is limited to the site of growth.: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Concepts.definition: A clinical and/or pathologic primary tumor TNM finding indicating that the cancer is limited to the site of growth.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term that refers to a TNM finding of a primary, non-invasive, papillary cancer.: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Concepts.definition: A term that refers to a TNM finding of a primary, non-invasive, papillary cancer.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm derived from the transitional epithelium of the urinary tract (urinary bladder, ureter, urethra, or renal pelvis). It is frequently papillary.: A malignant neoplasm arising from the transitional epithelium, usually affecting the urinary bladder, ureter, or renal pelvis. It may or may not have a papillary configuration. It is graded 1 to 3 or 4 according to the degree of cellular differentiation and architectural patterns. Grade 1 transitional cell carcinoma is histologically benign but it may recur. Transitional cell carcinomas may also affect the upper respiratory tract and the ovaries.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the urothelial lining of the urinary tract (bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra).

A malignant neoplasm arising from the transitional epithelium, usually affecting the urinary bladder, ureter, or renal pelvis. It may or may not have a papillary configuration. It is graded 1 to 3 or 4 according to the degree of cellular differentiation and architectural patterns. Grade 1 transitional cell carcinoma is histologically benign but it may recur. Transitional cell carcinomas may also affect the upper respiratory tract and the ovaries.
